37.text:
Great video, really enoyed the emphasis on the ancestor veneration, which i do agree we are tied to, one way or the other. However the soul trap or prison planet theory doesn't really convince me. 

First the whole theory is based on paranoia, who's to say the bad god, is actually the good god and they are also trapped by another even badder god, and so on. This type of fear will strip someone of all quality of life. Because its based on distrust, it lends to one self isolating. 

Next, if this is a prison, its a pretty shitty prison. Not only is it feasable to physically escape but also that this world is just as positive as it is negative, you cannot have one without the other, love without loss, joy without sadness, etc. so to point out all the negatives, call them truth, and then dismiss the positives as "spiritual false flags" seems to be a negative bias on the side of the perciever.

The last reason is motive, while it is possible that something is feeding or self-protecting by imprisoning us, it seems like a very biological thing to be happening because of an abstract existence. Like why would a metaphysical abstract entity need to eat or consume or protect? Those are all human aspects, not really applicable to non-biological entities. I dont think its fair to just assume things also have human-like motovation based on our internalized persepctive. 

Personally, i do believe in reincarnation. But i dont think this physical existence is a prison, hit rather an opportunity. All things have an informational dataset attatched to them, this dataset will always be unique. Every particle interaction, every atomic decay, is a novel action that has never happened before and never will happen again because all the "solutions" are a result of a recursive fractal absurdity. This recursive fractal existence produces only novel information/interactions, so in my opinion, it is likely that novelty is the motivation for creation. Everything is beautiful and unique, and while we may be temporary, our information is preserved through this interaction (essentially extended conciousness theory) this is how we are individual and interconnected. We feel both sides of negative and positive because they are both required for novel experience to happen. 
I do believe our information is "read" or observed by other entities, my belief would be that we are part of a fractally nested conciousness, stemming from the source of our universe (whatever that may be, personally i tend towards abstract polytheism). Material itself is the conduit, not our brains, though our behavior is highly novel and complex within the parameters of our universe, it is not the source of conciousness.

I can add to the royalty mystery. Most royalty had rh- blood. Rh- blood females have issues mating with rh+ blood. They can generally have one child, but will then have mostly miscarriages because the rh-female body sees the rh+ baby as a disease, so the immune system terminates it. Rh is the Rhesus factor. People who are rh+ have a protein on their blood cells similar to rhesus monkeys. Rh- people do not have that protein. That’s why O- blood is the universal donor, but cannot receive others’. There is a shot you can take if you are a rh- female and want to trick your immune system so your body doesn’t treat a baby as a disease. This is also why the US used to have mandated blood tests before you married. 

You’re welcome for your new rabbit hole. It’s a fun one. Get ready for ancient aliens…

74.text: Nature runs on cycles. Day and night, phases of the moon, the four seasons, precession of the equinoxes, the water cycle, the carbon cycle, etc. When applied to the afterlife you get the cycle of life, death, and rebirth. Some stages of these cycles are more pleasant than others, and the reason why reincarnation might seem cruel to you is that we are currently living through the worst part of the cycle. According to Hindu cosmology we are in the worst part of the Yuga cycle, the Kali Yuga, and according to Greek mythology we are in the worst of the Ages of Man, the Iron Age.

imho your most terrifying view is the correct one. 

Story goes that there is the Creator and the Creation. The Creator created the creation and is present in the creation but not the other way around. This statement is easily nullified by human logic and some philosophers have done so. So much for that.
 The soul, particles of the Creator in a "special form" are in prison in the creation because that is the life in the creation. This "life"needs to be contained for the creation to live. hence, the cycle of reincarnation and prison story.
 In the creation there are many mansions and in the many mansions there are many beings. the soul descends from the top down, interact in all these mansions, make a shitload of karma along the way in each mansion, so much that in cannot pay/neutralize it in a gazillion lives, one life is a joke.
 The creation is filled with life and is a living being so to speak. As in all living beings there is an asshole of some sorts, in this case this material plane where the human body can be found and in which a soul is reincarnated in along its journey through this creation. This can be compared (from the soul's perspective) to hitting the main motherfucker of all lotto's. 
The mind of the human is exceptional in its creativity, the five elements are present and it can create and enjoy many comforts and pleasures (survival, survival is a relative term, one man's death is another man's bread) which basically always result in pain and suffering because it is at the cost of energy transformed. 
There is nothing new under the sun and there is a certain ring to truth. 
There is not really anything new here.
Man's fundamental mission and believe in life is to survive on this earthly plane in his earthly body. This hard wiring starts already in the womb. When he comes to his senses some time after birth the process becomes clearer because that is all that he can understand. The more attention he pays to it, the better he becomes at it. At this point, in a manner of speaking, from the perspective of the soul he takes a turn down the wrong allay. 
His attention gets absorbed by the material world and the material world absorbs his attention and because of the five elements survival mode goes into overdrive with afterburners at max intensity. 
Just read history books and the Guinness Book of World Records. The apertures of the human body are the outlets of the attention and it goes ape shit at all the sensory information that it receives. The loose ends of sensory information turns into a crow's nest. Making sense of it consumes the time of man's life time.
The loose end of truth that can be picked up (by our attention) is the source of our consciousness. The attention, therefore needs to do a 180. imagine swimming against an ocean current, in this case, on steroids. I have heard it said, spirituality in Sanskrit means Supreme Achievement. No shit.
This loose end is the path on which the soul travels back to it's Source.
The swivel point is the eye center. Below it the attention flows down and out and above it it goes in and "up"
In the material world this golden thread is found in the teachings of some mystics who are in the category of all those that are classified as mystics. Alas, the golden thread is very fine and it is merely a map of the inner journey. maps are handy things for a traveler. 
In this world we see with our eyes and hear with our ears. in order to perceive form there need to be light. In order to hear something it needs to have a sound.
 Therefore outer light and sound.
 Our thoughts (kind off inner light and sound) are saturated with these outside experiences in outer light and sound. we name all the things we see and hear and it is difficult, for all practical purposes, for the attention not to see and hear these forms and the names (sound) of the forms that is in our thoughts. Everything we think of is related to the outside and the attention cannot reach the swivel point where the direction flips. When you think you have it is the same time you realize that you don't.
Some say that it is not difficult to enter the eye center and they can be right, however without the right map and knowledge and a little bit of something more, it might turn into a nightmare in the end.
There is of course more to the story.
Good luck in your search. We are all in the same boat.

135.text:
This is such an important video, you're awesome for making it. There's so much cultural bullshittery around reincarnation that it's become a horrible conversation. 

I've had a long and complicated struggle through my lifetime with what i believe to be residual memories/feelings/trauma from a lifetime outside of my own. It troubled me as a child, as a teenager, and it's only well into my adulthood that I'm coming to terms with it. I've always felt such resentment towards all of new agey circles that discuss this stuff, it seems so tainted with fraud.

Your point about DNA really struck me. I've always felt that I'm connected in a more tangible way to the person who's residual traumas I carry parts of. I too had always thought that i was fairly alone in that belief. 

Some years ago, i decided to try and trace my heritage as close to this 'past person' as i could, with only a name and a location hundreds of miles from my birthplace. Shockingly, i could trace a lineage from my own to within their county of birth. The chances of that must be astronomical.

We'll never know the answers to this stuff, and i guess those of us with experiences of it are destined to live alone with them if we wish to avoid ridicule. Seriously, thanks for making this  brother. It's really valuable to learn this shit

171.text: Not all Christians see heaven and hell as literal places. In Eastern Orthodox Christianity, they're more like states of being. After death, everyone experiences God's presence—because God is everywhere—but how you experience it depends on your soul. Those who love God feel His presence as joy and bliss (heaven), while those who reject Him feel his presence as fire and pain (hell). It's not some cartoon hell with the devil shoving pineapples up your ass all day, it's about how a soul responds to God's love. Some saints even believed it's possible for souls to repent after death and come to experience God as bliss. Also its interesting to know that the Gnostics who were an early sect of Christianity believed that this physical world is a kind of spiritual prison created by a lesser, flawed deity called the Demiurge—not the true, highest God. Our divine spark (soul) is trapped in material bodies, and the goal is to awaken through knowledge (gnosis), escape the illusions of this world, and return to the true spiritual realm beyond. It's more about escaping this corrupted reality than fixing it.

Whelp, looks like the Skeptic finally lost it.

The population bottleneck wasn't 10,000 years ago, it was 800,000 years ago. For perspective, Homo Sapiens is thought to have arisen in Africa around 300k years ago. The only people outside of Africa during that bottleneck were Homo Erectus.

Humanity didn't come back together til relatively recently. So like your "DNA is an antenna for the soul" thing kinda loses its logic there.

199.text:
Ok...
What if a person's ideal heaven is that of hedonism; sex, drugs, and rock and roll. Would that person's heaven be another person's version of hell? Would the typically understood version of heaven be the hedonists hell? What does hell look like for a sadomasicist or their heaven, for that matter? Are we all similar enough in likes and taste to say there's only one uniformed heaven and hell that functions as those places for everyone? Who's hell is who's heaven, whose heaven is who's hell. 

What about eternal consciousness. Can we truly understand what an eternal consciousness means? Or can we only conceptualize it? After all, eternal consciousness is enough time to know and do everything there is to know and do, and still have the rest of eternity to sit and do nothing. Suppose, after so long of maintaining consciousness, one grows weary of being conscious. Is there a way it? Is there a way to desist one's self from consciousness? After so long of existing and seeing so much, does one lose their sense of humanity and/or become numb due to over exposure? Does one eventually become consciously exhausted from continued consciousness? Are we really sure infinite consciousness is something good, or a hell in and of itself? Do we only fear death as desist of consciousness as a survival mechanism? 

This doesn't even get into meaning and purpose. Regardless of any type of theism or anti-theism, there seems to be a lack of reason for existence at all. Be that existence temporary, be that existence temporary until it is infinite, be that existence eternal consciousness. In asking the never-ending "why," one can easily come to the conclusion that not everything must have a reason or purpose. It would seem that some things merely are because they are. That not everything happens for a reason, but merely because it can and thus will or does. There is the possibility there is no intrinsic reason to being at all. Neither one for life itself or the spiritual aspect of eternal consciousness. Does the passage of time, or physics, work differently for those who exist in eternal consciousness? Only the dead seem to truly know, and the dead seem to tell no tales (as the saying goes). 

There's a book series called Sleeping Beauty (the thanantos files from different archives) by Stanley B. Burns, M.D. There are at least three volumes of this collection, there may be more. The collection of books is about post mortem daguerreotypes or other types of memorial photography. They include some poems, letters, and other written works from loved ones about their deceased. Within the written works one can peer into the thoughts of those grappling with the loss of a loved one in a time where death was so common place, it simply couldn't be ignored. The way culture viewed death in the 1800s was very different than that of today. Mourning and grieving was something of a cultural norm for them. They had entire shops dedicated to grief itself accompanying different garb for the different phases of grief one night go through. Post mortem photos were not viewed as strange or mcobre. In some instances a photo of a deceased loved one might have been the only photo of that loved one they even had. They would decorate their homes with these photos. They would be printed to hang on the walls, stand in a dual frame upon the mantel, or printed small for a locket to keep around ones neck. What is very interesting within the written work. Although supposedly a time when people were more religious, even then, they seemed to have a very clear concept of the desist of consciousness. They used phrasing such as "a dreamless sleep," or "an eternal darkness," and even the notion of a forever loss. In these books you can view pictures of these post mortem photos. Looking at them leaves one to ponder that the viewer is looking at one's own eventual inevitable fate for themselves. We can look and understand that these dead individuals are not only gone but long since forgotten. Their identities, especially the children, have been lost to time. Yet the viewer is left with the reality that they are glimpsing at real evidence of this individuals existence that one was and is no longer. Yes, they were once alive, walking around, interacting with their environment, interacting with our collective understanding that which is our reality. That these long since dead people once held or handled objects that those living today may be interacting with themselves, unaware of the deceased person who once did long before them. Door knobs they interacted with, a path they may have walked that we now walk ourselves, or maybe now occupied by some building. Possibly even where they were laid to rest. Bones and dust laying beneath the earth, forgotten, and lost to the sands of time. It can be chilling to realize this is all of our fate, and maybe that bothers us. For those that lived back then, ignoring the inevitable fate of death was a luxury they did not have as we do today; it was everywhere and all the time. It was a part of life, culture, society, and a way of life for them. 

Maybe we merely cling to things like religion because it makes us feel comfortable. For those in the past, despite the understanding of complete desist of consciousness. Religion did not serve for them a sense of comfort as it does for us today, but for those in the past it may have served as the only hope or coping mechanism they may have had. It didn't give them a sense of comfort because despite the idea of theism or eternal consciousness. It provided no escape from the reality of one's own mortality itself as they were surrounded by death everywhere and all the time. Religion did not change this and offered very little if any pithy rejoinder, unlike what it does for people in the modern eara.  It is truly fascinating and terrifying to ponder, really.  

To the conservative mind, the idea of returning to the past as an idea that somehow the past was better. As you peer into history and read the poetry of the grief from one who has lost a loved one while looking at an old photo of the one who died. You can glean into the various causes of death that made death so common and taking place in every household. If we want to return to a better time, look no further than the one we currently exist in because you're already living in it. No longer do we lose our loved ones left and right, and everywhere and all the time due to things like: tooth decay, viral and bacterial infections, simple injuries, being buried alive (which might be the most brutal way to die), giving birth, products made with deadly amounts of poison like the radium girls, simple accidents, broken bones, contaminated water, used bath water (this is where the phrase don't throw the baby out with the bathwater comes from), exposure to improperly disposed of corpses, improper sewage disposal, disability, famine, drought, isolation, rampant crime and murder, a corrupt law and justice system, birth defects and deformities, contaminated food supply, and many more things we do not worry about today. There are people today who are undermining the things people in the past put in place so that we may lead a better life than they ever did. We are seeing a resurgence of these issues as they are drunk on a drug called nostalgia. As if appeals to tradition were not a form of logical fallacy, but they are.  For those that want to return to the past, maybe they should look at how those in the past actually lived or lack thereof. It's become so prevalent. Those in ancient Greece would roll human feces around in herbs, then use this to dress a wound. Despite our modern understanding of health and germ theory, there is even a revival of this treatment. They did it in the past, therefore it must be more effective than what we do today; as though they had some ancient knowledge we have forgotten for the sake of making money with medications. If we continue down this path, we will once again find ourselves surrounded by death again. A way of life those long since dead wanted to deliver themselves and the future humans (us) from. If only the dead could tell us their story in person, in the flesh. The only story they can tell us is from what they left behind. Writings, daguerreotypes, tintypes, copper types, bodies, and documentation of the dead. A way of communicating not through a continued consciousness but trace evidence they left behind of their finite life and how they lived. 

"There is no point in dwelling on the  dreams of the dead" - Lord Liu Bie's son of the Shu-Han dynasty Liu Shan the fall of the dynasty of Shu to the dynasty of Jin-Wei 271 CE.

Hey buddy. Wonderful video.

I've studied this topic in great detail. You need to go read Robert Monroe's trilogy that starts with, "Journeys Out of the Body." It's the missing key you need for this topic. You'll discover the origin of the term, "Loosh" and how most people in the Escaping Prison Planet group don't fully understand how this is all actually playing out. Also, you'll learn a lot more mind-blowing stuff. All of the afterlifes are real. It's all no more than a dream where our mind shapes our reality, and there will be collective pocket planes where all religions and their respective members will carry on with business as usual in a new afterlife frame post-death. The more lucid we become, the more in control we become of our own destinies. We don't just "figure it all out" when we die. The game goes on for many. This is why the more open minded NDE's went in one direction and the more religious-minded NDE's went in another.

This 3D reality is a collective dream, unlike our night-time romping, so to change our reality here we'd need enough people focused on the same things. This is why we're kept divided, and also why most "miracles" or "magic" is preformed in secret where the collective Will of a small group can be amped up enough without the interference of the public collective. World leaders of religions keep these secrets to themselves and use them, while controlling the rest of us and feeding us bullshit lies.

Anyway, I'm pretty sure we all (or most of us anyway), willingly chose to come to Earth. Every soul has its own story, history and reasons for coming here. We did not all come from the same "God/Origin" (Not until you go all the way back to Source, anyway.) We're all visitors sharing an Earth experience, and some of us forget who we are and our task is to remember. Once we remember who we are, getting off this son of a bitch life-eats-life planet will be a lot easier.  Meditation and Out-Of-Body experiences are a part of it. (The powers that be have done everything they can to make our physical bodies less sensitive to these higher energies through poisoning us in a variety of ways, and it's also why marijuana and psychedelics have been illegal for so long.) 

Likely, the "amnesia" of who we are doesn't hit us on our first incarnation. We just get addicted to the Earth experience and slowly forget. Ego is a rush, especially when you're winning, or learning to win at the game. So a fresher soul to the game reincarnates because it wants another hit of that cocaine like egoic feeling of being champion and conqueror. Over time, this takes over and we forget who we are. This is also why the psychedelic movement in the 60's changed everything.

Free your mind and you'll have so many more options post-death. Hope this gives some insight. Cheers.

346.text:
I walked the Rainbow Bridge almost 20 years ago after a slip and fall onto a bathroom floor on top of some glass. I had a blackout (vegas nerve they think) and fell onto the glass I was drinking from. It slit my wrist and missed that main vein by a millimeter. Had massive blood loss, but was luckily woken up by my mom busting through the door and the door hitting my head. My Grandmother and Aunt who had passed before were there as "I" was lifted off of that bathroom floor and into an intense light. When I reached that light, I was standing on the Rainbow Bridge. 20 years later, I really only remember it in bits and pieces, but I remember meeting these "entities" that were... "blurred" as well as other "people" like me. The only way I can rationalize the "blurry" ones is that maybe I just couldn't comprehend what they actually were because there were other........ creatures or entities there. We all seemed to be waiting for something as lines were formed. Most of us confused. That's when I was woken up and pulled back. I've been back before, but only when I'm getting really good sleep..... but I haven't got that kind of sleep in years. 20 years of mulling it over and I have come to think of it as "The Grand Central Station in the Sky". I once was woken up from deep sleep by my girlfriend who had yelped after burning herself with her curling iron. I shot up to run and see what was happening, made it 3 or 4 steps, and hit the floor blacked out. Before I came to, I remember entering the solar system, zooming past all the planets, and then entering earth's atmosphere before slamming into my body and waking up. That's the day I went to the doctor about it. 
I have some opinions about what I witnessed, but to sum it up, I think we've only scratched the surface of what's really going on. Of course, what I witnessed on that floor could have all just been that final release of DMT while I lay dying? 🤷‍♂

359.text:
I keep having memories of my childhood plague me now that I'm a dad of four. I was an only child, and my father always punished me more and more, thinking I won't screw up if my punishment was harder than last time. From 5 years old my dad would spank me and put me in bed where I wasn't allowed any entertainment, toys, books, etc. I couldn't fall asleep before 10pm or I'd get spanked again and double punishment - my punishments were regularly an entire week long in isolation. This memory hit me the other day when I was play fighting my cousin when we switched to sticks and I hit him causing him to cry and tell on me - I begged and begged him not to and that I was so sorry, I was crying at him - he told my dad anyway and he immediately punished me for 3 days in bed for "hitting him". I'll never forget as they left, my older cousin said to my dad "he didn't just hit him, he hit him with a stick" and my dad "WHAAAAT!? He hit him with a stick?!" - 2 seconds later he was back and spanked the shiiiiit out of me (20?) and I got my first 2 week bed-ridden punishment. I've been scalded by hot shower water and tortured with freezing water and once got an entire month in bed and both field trip forms for that month (end of school year - 4th grade) were ripped up.

Why am I telling you this? Your story resonated with me and I too wonder what poor little Greg did that was so bad. My oldest is eleven and he never experienced longer than a 5 minute time-out, maybe once or twice in his life. Why was I so punished? People knew my dad would punish me badly too and tell on me to be mean. Once I sung a song my dad always listened to with the word "pissed" in it, but I didn't know it was a bad word - they threatened me to tell my dad for over an hour just to mess with me, which I pleaded not to, that I didn't know and I won't say it again (keep in mind these 2 kids swore openly), and those F'ers told my dad anyway - yep, belt, soap, 2 weeks. Amen. Hallelujah. Thanks be to God. I'm a little cynical about the whole thing still and I'm almost 36. It's not easy to understand nor heal from!

396.text:
Well, I can prove it. This place is worse than your worst nightmares. Endless suffering and pain. 
When you are pushed back, there is a high chance you will stay in your bloodline. So I have tested a lot of newborns in my family tree with old pictures (grandparents and above), and some of them reacted to touching their own face, and when I started saying random names and the name of the one in the picture came up, they looked at me immediately. 
When your extended family has a baby and you wonder why he/she goes to you, randomly hugs your le,g or looks at you for a long time in silence or randomly smiles at you... Well, it might be because she/he was one of your grandparents or other older family members, and you were really close to each other.
Have you ever wondered why newborns forget how to swim at 6, if instincts cannot be forgotten? Because those were memories...
The worst part is that there are no 3rd party (without the creator of this place and its gatekeepers) out there who would erase this system, which makes you think the outside is even more evil.
My friends and I are trying to figure out how to rip apart our own souls into nothing so we can stop this endless suffering. It is much better to not exist than to suffer forever.
And remember, the worst thing that can happen in hell is to make a child. STOP!
